section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need five yellow Connecting Cubes and materials to represent a bridge, such as building blocks or a few books.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Ducks Away!, we counted the number of ducklings on the bridge and the number of ducklings that toppled into the water below.
Let’s review the words toppled and below.Use toppled and below Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
In this activity, we will use five Connecting Cubes to show the five ducks crossing the bridge. As the ducks topple over, we will say how many are still on the bridge, and how many are now below.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Build a small bridge using building blocks or books, and place the five yellow Connecting Cubes on top. Ask, How many ducklings are on the bridge? Have children count the Connecting Cubes aloud.
Topple Ask a child to move one cube below the bridge. There were five ducklings on the bridge. Then one toppled off! How many ducklings are on the bridge now? How many are below? Let’s count and see.

Repeat Continue to ask children to move one cube at a time below the bridge. Each time, ask children to tell how many ducklings are on the bridge and how many are in the water. Ask for the total number of ducks, emphasizing that each combination of ducks equals five in all.
Discuss Talk with children about the math concepts in the activity. We counted the ducklings in many different orders. Did that change the total number of ducklings there were?

Start with three Connecting Cubes. Model moving a cube below the bridge, and think aloud about the numbers of ducklings: There were three ducklings on the bridge. One toppled below. If I count back one from three, I get two. There are two ducklings left on the bridge.
Challenge children to move more than one duckling at a time below the bridge. You may also switch the activity around by having some ducklings “fly back” onto the bridge.
Review key vocabulary, such as ducklings, bridge, and on. Touch each cube to show where you would like children to start counting, and count with them to help reinforce number vocabulary.

To help children with sensory needs focus on the activity, play soothing music to drown out background noises. You may also provide gloves for children who have difficulty touching the cubes with their bare hands, or offer to move the ducklings for them.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65576-6. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need about thirty Connecting Cubes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Ducks Away!, we talked about making equal groups and using teamwork to create new things.
Let’s review the words teamwork and cooperate.Use teamwork and cooperate Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
In this activity, we will use Connecting Cubes to represent ducklings. We will work with partners to split the ducklings into two groups with the same number in each group.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Pair children and give each pair eight Connecting Cubes.

Group Ask partners to cooperate and use teamwork to split the Connecting Cubes into two equal groups. Once children have finished, ask each pair, How did you separate your ducklings into two groups? How can you tell there are the same amount of ducklings in each group? Can you count to make sure they are equal?
Repeat Give each pair two more Connecting Cubes, so that partners have a total of 10. Have children split the 10 ducklings into two equal groups, and again ask each pair to describe how they did it.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What was easy about separating your ducklings into two groups with the same amount? What was difficult? How did you cooperate with your partner? Do you think the activity was easier because you used teamwork?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Give each pair four Connecting Cubes to start, and then move to six. Model separating four Connecting Cubes into equal groups while thinking aloud: If I move one cube into another group, I have one here and three there. What happens if I move two?
Challenge children to separate their cubes into more than two equal groups (eight cubes into four groups of two, 10 cubes into five groups of two). Ask, How many equal groups can you make?

Pair multilingual learners with partners who have the same home language, if possible. Children may feel more comfortable working with a partner if they can speak to one another relatively easily. When describing the task, use the word equal and share the cognate igual with Spanish speakers.

Have pairs work in different areas of the room so that children do not become distracted by what the other pairs are doing. If children need further focusing strategies, encourage them to count the cubes in as many orders as they can while separating them into groups.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65576-6. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Ducks Away!, we talked about where the ducklings were on the page using the words up and down.
Let’s review the words up and down.Use the up and down Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
In this activity, I will show you Activity Cards with pictures that show something or someone going up or down. You will tell me whether the pictures show up or down.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show children the first Activity Card. Ask whether the picture shows up or down, and challenge children to explain how they can tell.
Extend Ask children to describe something else that can go or move up or down, similar to what is shown in the picture. Encourage children to use their own experiences to answer.

Repeat Continue the activity until all of the Activity Cards have been shown. Have children go through the cards a second time, this time creating one pile for up and one for down. Challenge children to determine which pile contains more cards.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Was it easy to tell which pictures showed up or down? What was difficult about it? What other location words could you use to describe these pictures?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: As you show each Activity Card to children, move your finger along the picture to model the direction of the object, animal, or person shown. Model thinking aloud about which direction you see: This bird is facing the water. That means it’s flying down.
Challenge children to sort the cards into two groups: up and down. Ask children whether it is possible to sort nine cards into two equal groups, and have them explain why it is not.

As you say the words up and down, use hand gestures such as raising a hand in the air or angling it down to the ground to reinforce the terms. Encourage children to answer using hand gestures as well.

Have children pretend to move up or down like the object, animal, or person in the picture. They can spread their arms to fly like a plane, wiggle up like a floating balloon, or pretend to jump down like a cat.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65576-6. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need five Two-Color Counters and masking tape to create a finish line.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read I Like to Race, we learned about racing and practiced counting.
In this activity, we will use counters to represent racers. We will take turns moving the racers across the finish line and telling how many racers are still in the race.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Create a finish line on the table using tape. Line up the five Two-Color Counters at the other end of the table, as if starting a race.

First Place Invite a child to move one of the racers across the finish line. Ask, How many racers are left in the race? Guide the child to count back one from five to say how many racers are left. Then, ask a child to count the remaining four counters. Ask another child to count them in a different order. Are there still four racers?

Repeat Continue to invite children to move racers across the finish line. Each time, ask children to tell you how many racers are left, and ask two more children to count them. As each racer crosses the finish line, ask children to say how many racers have finished and how many haven’t raced yet.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How many racers were there in all? Even though the racers were moving, were there still always five in all? How did it feel to move a counter over the finish line? Would you want to race? Why or why not?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Create a 5-frame on the table out of masking tape. Use the red side of the counter to represent racers at the starting line, and flip the racer over to yellow once it crosses the finish line. Encourage children to use the 5-frame to say how many racers have and haven’t raced.
Use 10 Two-Color Counters, and challenge children to move more than one across the finish line at a time.
Revisit key vocabulary, such as race, racer, and finish line, as well as numbers 1–5. Use Number Cards, inviting children to show the Number Card that matches the number of racers in each group.

If space allows, have children act as the counters. Select children to “race” to a designated finish line across the room or outside, and have children say and count how many children have already raced and how many have not yet. You may also place the counters on a longer table or on the floor, and encourage children to walk with the counter over to the designated finish line.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65576-6. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved
